That is why\nwe have the explicit check `if request`.\n\n## Mounting Within Another FastAPI App\n\nIn some cases, you might have an existing FastAPI app, and you'd like to add a path for a Gradio demo.\nYou can easily do this with `gradio.mount_gradio_app()`.\n\nHere's a complete example:\n\n```python\nfrom fastapi import FastAPI\nimport gradio as gr\n\nCUSTOM_PATH = \"/gradio\"\n\napp = FastAPI()\n\n@app.get(\"/\")\ndef read_main():\n    return {\"message\": \"This is your main app\"}\n\nio = gr.Interface(lambda x: \"Hello, \" + x + \"!\", \"textbox\", \"textbox\")\napp = gr.mount_gradio_app(app, io, path=CUSTOM_PATH)\n\n# Run this from the terminal as you would normally start a FastAPI app: `uvicorn run:app`\n# and navigate to http://localhost:8000/gradio in your browser.\n\n```\n\nNote that this approach also allows you run your Gradio apps on custom paths (`http://localhost:8000/gradio` in the example above).\n\n\n## Authentication\n\n### Password-protected app\n\nYou may wish to put an authentication page in front of your app to limit who can open your app. With the `auth=` keyword argument in the `launch()` method, you can provide a tuple with a username and password, or a list of acceptable username/password tuples; Here's an example that provides password-based authentication for a single user named \"admin\":\n\n```python\ndemo.launch(auth=(\"admin\", \"pass1234\"))\n```\n\nFor more complex authentication handling, you can even pass a function that takes a username and password as arguments, and returns `True` to allow access, `False` otherwise.\n\nHere's an example of a function that accepts any login where the username and password are the same:\n\n```python\ndef same_auth(username, password):\n    return username == password\ndemo.launch(auth=same_auth)\n```\n\nIf you have multiple users, you may wish to customize the content that is shown depending on the user that is logged in. You can retrieve the logged in user by [accessing the network request directly](#accessing-the-network-request-directly) as discussed above, and then reading the `.username` attribute of the request. Here's an example:\n\n\n```python\nimport gradio as gr\n\ndef update_message(request: gr.Request):\n    return f\"Welcome, {request.username}\"\n\nwith gr.Blocks() as demo:\n    m = gr.Markdown()\n    demo.load(update_message, None, m)\n\ndemo.launch(auth=[(\"Abubakar\", \"Abubakar\"), (\"Ali\", \"Ali\")])\n```\n\nNote: For authentication to work properly, third party cookies must be enabled in your browser. This is not the case by default for Safari or for Chrome Incognito Mode.\n\nIf users visit the `/logout` page of your Gradio app, they will automatically be logged out and session cookies deleted. This allows you to add logout functionality to your Gradio app as well. Let's update the previous example to include a log out button:\n\n```python\nimport gradio as gr\n\ndef update_message(request: gr.Request):\n    return f\"Welcome, {request.username}\"\n\nwith gr.Blocks() as demo:\n    m = gr.Markdown()\n    logout_button = gr.Button(\"Logout\", link=\"/logout\")\n    demo.load(update_message, None, m)\n\ndemo.launch(auth=[(\"Pete\", \"Pete\"), (\"Dawood\", \"Dawood\")])\n```\nBy default, visiting `/logout` logs the user out from **all sessions** (e.g. if they are logged in from multiple browsers or devices, all will be signed out). If you want to log out only from the **current session**, add the query parameter `all_session=false` (i.e. `/logout?all_session=false`).\n\nNote: Gradio's built-in authentication provides a straightforward and basic layer of access control but does not offer robust security features for applications that require stringent access controls (e.g.  multi-factor authentication, rate limiting, or automatic lockout policies).\n\n### OAuth (Login via Hugging Face)\n\nGradio natively supports OAuth login via Hugging Face. In other words, you can easily add a _\"Sign in with Hugging Face\"_ button to your demo, which allows you to get a user's HF username as well as other information from their HF profile. Check out [this Space](https://huggingface.co/spaces/Wauplin/gradio-oauth-demo) for a live demo.\n\nTo enable OAuth, you must set `hf_oauth: true` as a Space metadata in your README.md file. This will register your Space\nas an OAuth application on Hugging Face. Next, you can use `gr.LoginButton` to add a login button to\nyour Gradio app. Once a user is logged in with their HF account, you can retrieve their profile by adding a parameter of type\n`gr.OAuthProfile` to any Gradio function. The user profile will be automatically injected as a parameter value. If you want\nto perform actions on behalf of the user (e.g. list user's private repos, create repo, etc.), you can retrieve the user\ntoken by adding a parameter of type `gr.OAuthToken`. You must define which scopes you will use in your Space metadata\n(see [documentation](https://huggingface.co/docs/hub/spaces-oauth#scopes) for more details).\n\nHere is a short example:\n\n```python\nfrom __future__ import annotations\n\nimport gradio as gr\nfrom huggingface_hub import whoami\n\ndef hello(profile: gr.OAuthProfile | None) -> str:\n    if profile is None:\n        return \"I don't know you.\"\n    return f\"Hello {profile.name}\"\n\ndef list_organizations(oauth_token: gr.OAuthToken | None) -> str:\n    if oauth_token is None:\n        return \"Please deploy this on Spaces and log in to list organizations.\"\n    org_names = [org[\"name\"] for org in whoami(oauth_token.token)[\"orgs\"]]\n    return f\"You belong to {', '.join(org_names)}.\"\n\nwith gr.Blocks() as demo:\n    gr.LoginButton()\n    m1 = gr.Markdown()\n    m2 = gr.Markdown()\n    demo.load(hello, inputs=None, outputs=m1)\n    demo.load(list_organizations, inputs=None, outputs=m2)\n\ndemo.launch()\n\n```\n\nWhen the user clicks on the login button, they get redirected in a new page to authorize your Space.\n\n\u003Ccenter>\n\u003Cimg src=\"https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/gradio-guides/oauth_sign_in.png\" style=\"width:300px; max-width:80%\">\n\u003C/center>\n\nUsers can revoke access to their profile at any time in their [settings](https://huggingface.co/settings/connected-applications).\n\nAs seen above, OAuth features are available only when your app runs in a Space. However, you often need to test your app\nlocally before deploying it. To test OAuth features locally, your machine must be logged in to Hugging Face. Please run `huggingface-cli login` or set `HF_TOKEN` as environment variable with one of your access token. You can generate a new token in your settings page (https://huggingface.co/settings/tokens). Then, clicking on the `gr.LoginButton` will log in to your local Hugging Face profile, allowing you to debug your app with your Hugging Face account before deploying it to a Space.\n\n**Security Note**: It is important to note that adding a `gr.LoginButton` does not restrict users from using your app, in the same way that adding [username-password authentication](/guides/sharing-your-app#password-protected-app) does. This means that users of your app who have not logged in with Hugging Face can still access and run events in your Gradio app -- the difference is that the `gr.OAuthProfile` or `gr.OAuthToken` will be `None` in the corresponding functions.\n\n\n### OAuth (with external providers)\n\nIt is also possible to authenticate with external OAuth providers (e.g. Google OAuth) in your Gradio apps. To do this, first mount your Gradio app within a FastAPI app ([as discussed above](#mounting-within-another-fast-api-app)). Then, you must write an *authentication function*, which gets the user's username from the OAuth provider and returns it. This function should be passed to the `auth_dependency` parameter in `gr.mount_gradio_app`.\n\nSimilar to [FastAPI dependency functions](https://fastapi.tiangolo.com/tutorial/dependencies/), the function specified by `auth_dependency` will run before any Gradio-related route in your FastAPI app. The function should accept a single parameter: the FastAPI `Request` and return either a string (representing a user's username) or `None`. If a string is returned, the user will be able to access the Gradio-related routes in your FastAPI app.\n\nFirst, let's show a simplistic example to illustrate the `auth_dependency` parameter:\n\n```python\nfrom fastapi import FastAPI, Request\nimport gradio as gr\n\napp = FastAPI()\n\ndef get_user(request: Request):\n    return request.headers.get(\"user\")\n\ndemo = gr.Interface(lambda s: f\"Hello {s}!\", \"textbox\", \"textbox\")\n\napp = gr.mount_gradio_app(app, demo, path=\"/demo\", auth_dependency=get_user)\n\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    uvicorn.run(app)\n```\n\nIn this example, only requests that include a \"user\" header will be allowed to access the Gradio app. Of course, this does not add much security, since any user can add this header in their request.\n\nHere's a more complete example showing how to add Google OAuth to a Gradio app (assuming you've already created OAuth Credentials on the [Google Developer Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/project)):\n\n```python\nimport os\nfrom authlib.integrations.starlette_client import OAuth, OAuthError\nfrom fastapi import FastAPI, Depends, Request\nfrom starlette.config import Config\nfrom starlette.responses import RedirectResponse\nfrom starlette.middleware.sessions import SessionMiddleware\nimport uvicorn\nimport gradio as gr\n\napp = FastAPI()\n\n# Replace these with your own OAuth settings\nGOOGLE_CLIENT_ID = \"...\"\nGOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET = \"...\"\nSECRET_KEY = \"...\"\n\nconfig_data = {'GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID': GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID, 'GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET': GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET}\nstarlette_config = Config(environ=config_data)\noauth = OAuth(starlette_config)\noauth.register(\n    name='google',\n    server_metadata_url='https://accounts.google.com/.well-known/openid-configuration',\n    client_kwargs={'scope': 'openid email profile'},\n)\n\nSECRET_KEY = os.environ.get('SECRET_KEY') or \"a_very_secret_key\"\napp.add_middleware(SessionMiddleware, secret_key=SECRET_KEY)\n\n# Dependency to get the current user\ndef get_user(request: Request):\n    user = request.session.get('user')\n    if user:\n        return user['name']\n    return None\n\n@app.get('/')\ndef public(user: dict = Depends(get_user)):\n    if user:\n        return RedirectResponse(url='/gradio')\n    else:\n        return RedirectResponse(url='/login-demo')\n\n@app.route('/logout')\nasync def logout(request: Request):\n    request.session.pop('user', None)\n    return RedirectResponse(url='/')\n\n@app.route('/login')\nasync def login(request: Request):\n    redirect_uri = request.url_for('auth')\n    # If your app is running on https, you should ensure that the\n    # `redirect_uri` is https, e.g. uncomment the following lines:\n    #\n    # from urllib.parse import urlparse, urlunparse\n    # redirect_uri = urlunparse(urlparse(str(redirect_uri))._replace(scheme='https'))\n    return await oauth.google.authorize_redirect(request, redirect_uri)\n\n@app.route('/auth')\nasync def auth(request: Request):\n    try:\n        access_token = await oauth.google.authorize_access_token(request)\n    except OAuthError:\n        return RedirectResponse(url='/')\n    request.session['user'] = dict(access_token)[\"userinfo\"]\n    return RedirectResponse(url='/')\n\nwith gr.Blocks() as login_demo:\n    gr.Button(\"Login\", link=\"/login\")\n\napp = gr.mount_gradio_app(app, login_demo, path=\"/login-demo\")\n\ndef greet(request: gr.Request):\n    return f\"Welcome to Gradio, {request.username}\"\n\nwith gr.Blocks() as main_demo:\n    m = gr.Markdown(\"Welcome to Gradio!\")\n    gr.Button(\"Logout\", link=\"/logout\")\n    main_demo.load(greet, None, m)\n\napp = gr.mount_gradio_app(app, main_demo, path=\"/gradio\", auth_dependency=get_user)\n\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    uvicorn.run(app)\n```\n\nThere are actually two separate Gradio apps in this example! One that simply displays a log in button (this demo is accessible to any user), while the other main demo is only accessible to users that are logged in. You can try this example out on [this Space](https://huggingface.co/spaces/gradio/oauth-example).\n\n## MCP Servers\n\nGradio apps can function as MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers, allowing LLMs to use your app's functions as tools. By simply setting `mcp_server=True` in the `.launch()` method, Gradio automatically converts your app's functions into MCP tools that can be called by MCP clients like Claude Desktop, Cursor, or Cline. The server exposes tools based on your function names, docstrings, and type hints, and can handle file uploads, authentication headers, and progress updates. You can also create MCP-only functions using `gr.api` and expose resources and prompts using decorators. For a comprehensive guide on building MCP servers with Gradio, see [Building an MCP Server with Gradio](https://www.gradio.app/guides/building-mcp-server-with-gradio).\n\n## Rate Limits\n\nWhen publishing your app publicly, and making it available via API or via MCP server, you might want to set rate limits to prevent users from abusing your app. You can identify users using their IP address (using the `gr.Request` object [as discussed above](#accessing-the-network-request-directly)) or, if they are logged in via Hugging Face OAuth, using their username. To see a complete example of how to set rate limits, please see [this Gradio app](https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/blob/main/demo/rate_limit/run.py).\n\n## Analytics\n\nBy default, Gradio collects certain analytics to help us better understand the usage of the `gradio` library. This includes the following information:\n\n* What environment the Gradio app is running on (e.g. Colab Notebook, Hugging Face Spaces)\n* What input/output components are being used in the Gradio app\n* Whether the Gradio app is utilizing certain advanced features, such as `auth` or `show_error`\n* The IP address which is used solely to measure the number of unique developers using Gradio\n* The version of Gradio that is running\n\nNo information is collected from _users_ of your Gradio app. If you'd like to disable analytics altogether, you can do so by setting the `analytics_enabled` parameter to `False` in `gr.Blocks`, `gr.Interface`, or `gr.ChatInterface`. Or, you can set the GRADIO_ANALYTICS_ENABLED environment variable to `\"False\"` to apply this to all Gradio apps created across your system.\n\n*Note*: this reflects the analytics policy as of `gradio>=4.32.0`.\n\n## Progressive Web App (PWA)\n\n[Progressive Web Apps (PWAs)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Progressive_web_apps) are web applications that are regular web pages or websites, but can appear to the user like installable platform-specific applications.\n\nGradio apps can be easily served as PWAs by setting the `pwa=True` parameter in the `launch()` method. Here's an example:\n\n```python\nimport gradio as gr\n\ndef greet(name):\n    return \"Hello \" + name + \"!\"\n\ndemo = gr.Interface(fn=greet, inputs=\"textbox\", outputs=\"textbox\")\n\ndemo.launch(pwa=True)  # Launch your app as a PWA\n```\n\nThis will generate a PWA that can be installed on your device. Here's how it looks:\n\n![Installing PWA](https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/gradio-guides/install-pwa.gif)\n\nWhen you specify `favicon_path` in the `launch()` method, the icon will be used as the app's icon. Here's an example:\n\n```python\ndemo.launch(pwa=True, favicon_path=\"./hf-logo.svg\")  # Use a custom icon for your PWA\n```\n\n![Custom PWA Icon](https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/gradio-guides/pwa-favicon.png)\n",tags:[],spaces:[],url:"/guides/sharing-your-app/",contributor:null,new_html:"\u003Cscript>\nfetch(\"https://pypi.org/pypi/gradio/json\"\n).then(r => r.json()\n).then(obj => {\n    let v = obj.info.version;\n    content = document.querySelector('.prose');\n    content.innerHTML = content.innerHTML.replaceAll(\"{GRADIO_VERSION}\", v);\n});\n\u003C/script>\n\n\u003Ch1>Sharing Your App\u003C/h1>\n\u003Cp>In this Guide, we dive more deeply into the various aspects of sharing a Gradio app with others. Spaces\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca href=\"#sharing-deep-links\">Sharing Deep Links\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca href=\"#embedding-hosted-spaces\">Embedding hosted spaces\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca href=\"#api-page\">Using the API page\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca href=\"#accessing-the-network-request-directly\">Accessing network requests\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca href=\"#mounting-within-another-fast-api-app\">Mounting within FastAPI\u003C/a>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ca  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>Gradio demos can be easily shared publicly by setting \u003Ccode>share=True\u003C/code> in the \u003Ccode>launch()\u003C/code> method. \u003Cspan class=\"token comment\"># Share your demo with just 1 extra parameter \u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>This generates a public, shareable link that you can send to anybody! When you send this link, the user on the other side can try out the model in their browser. Because the processing happens on your device (as long as your device stays on), you don't have to worry about any packaging any dependencies.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/blob/main/guides/assets/sharing.svg?raw=true\"\n  alt=\"sharing\"\n>\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>A share link usually looks something like this: \u003Cstrong>\u003Ca\n  href=\"https://07ff8706ab.gradio.live\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>https://07ff8706ab.gradio.live\u003C/a>\u003C/strong>. Although the link is served through the Gradio Share Servers, these servers are only a proxy for your local server, and do not store any data sent through your app. Share links expire after 1 week. (it is \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://github.com/huggingface/frp/\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>also possible to set up your own Share Server\u003C/a> on your own cloud server to overcome this restriction.)\u003C/p>\n            \u003Cdiv class='tip'>\n                \u003Csvg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 24 24\" fill=\"none\" stroke=\"currentColor\" stroke-width=\"2\" stroke-linecap=\"round\" stroke-linejoin=\"round\">\n                    \u003Cpath d=\"M15 14c.2-1 .7-1.7 1.5-2.5 1-.9 1.5-2.2 1.5-3.5A6 6 0 0 0 6 8c0 1 .2 2.2 1.5 3.5.7.7 1.3 1.5 1.5 2.5\"/>\n                    \u003Cpath d=\"M9 18h6\"/>\n                    \u003Cpath d=\"M10 22h4\"/>\n                \u003C/svg>\n                \u003Cdiv>\u003Cp>Keep in mind that share links are publicly accessible, meaning that anyone can use your model for prediction! Therefore, make sure not to expose any sensitive information through the functions you write, or allow any critical changes to occur on your device. Or you can \u003Ca href=\"#authentication\">add authentication to your Gradio app\u003C/a> as discussed below.\u003C/p>\u003C/div>\n            \u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>Note that by default, \u003Ccode>share=False\u003C/code>, which means that your server is only running locally. (This is the default, except in Google Colab notebooks, where share links are automatically created). As an alternative to using share links, you can use use \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://www.ssh.com/ssh/tunneling/example\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>SSH port-forwarding\u003C/a> to share your local server with specific users.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch2 class=\"group\" id=\"hosting-on-hf-spaces\">Hosting on HF Spaces\u003Ca\n  href=\"#hosting-on-hf-spaces\"\n  class=\"invisible group-hover-visible\"\n>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>If you'd like to have a permanent link to your Gradio demo on the internet, use Hugging Face Spaces. \u003Ca\n  href=\"http://huggingface.co/spaces/\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>Hugging Face Spaces\u003C/a> provides the infrastructure to permanently host your machine learning model for free!\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>After you have \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/join\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>created a free Hugging Face account\u003C/a>, you have two methods to deploy your Gradio app to Hugging Face Spaces:\u003C/p>\n\u003Col>\n\u003Cli>\n\u003Cp>From terminal: run \u003Ccode>gradio deploy\u003C/code> in your app directory. The CLI will gather some basic metadata, upload all the files in the current directory (respecting any \u003Ccode>.gitignore\u003C/code> file that may be present in the root of the directory), and then launch your app on Spaces. To update your Space, you can re-run this command or enable the Github Actions option in the CLI to automatically update the Spaces on \u003Ccode>git push\u003C/code>.\u003C/p>\n\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\n\u003Cp>From your browser: Drag and drop a folder containing your Gradio model and all related files \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/new-space\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>here\u003C/a>. See \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/blog/gradio-spaces\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>this guide how to host on Hugging Face Spaces\u003C/a> for more information, or watch the embedded video:\u003C/p>\n\u003C/li>\n\u003C/ol>\n\u003Cvideo autoplay muted loop>\n  \u003Csource src=\"https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/blob/main/guides/assets/hf_demo.mp4?raw=true\" type=\"video/mp4\" src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>You can add a button to your Gradio app that creates a unique URL you can use to share your app and all components \u003Cstrong>as they currently are\u003C/strong> with others. This is useful for sharing unique and interesting generations from your application , or for saving a snapshot of your app at a particular point in time.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>To add a deep link button to your app, place the \u003Ccode>gr.DeepLinkButton\u003C/code> component anywhere in your app.\nFor the URL to be accessible to others, your app must be available at a public URL. So be sure to host your app like Hugging Face Spaces or use the \u003Ccode>share=True\u003C/code> parameter when launching your app.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Let's see an example of how this works. Here's a simple Gradio chat ap that uses the \u003Ccode>gr.DeepLinkButton\u003C/code> component. After a couple of messages, click the deep link button and paste it into a new browser tab to see the app as it is at that point in time.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> gradio \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">as\u003C/span> gr\n\u003Cspan class=\"token  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>Once you have hosted your app on Hugging Face Spaces (or on your own server), you may want to embed the demo on a different website, such as your blog or your portfolio. Embedding an interactive demo allows people to try out the machine learning model that you have built, without needing to download or install anything  right in their browser! The best part is that you can embed interactive demos even in static websites, such as GitHub pages.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>There are two ways to embed your Gradio demos. You can find quick links to both options directly on the Hugging Face Space page, in the \"Embed this Space\" dropdown option:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/blob/main/guides/assets/embed_this_space.png?raw=true\"\n  alt=\"Embed this Space dropdown option\"\n>\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch3\n  class=\"group\"\n  id=\"embedding-with-web-components\"\n>Embedding with Web Components\u003Ca\n  href=\"#embedding-with-web-components\"\n  class=\"invisible group-hover-visible\"\n>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h3>\n\u003Cp>Web components typically offer a better experience to users than IFrames. Web components load lazily, meaning that they won't slow down the loading time of your website, and they automatically adjust their height based on the size of the Gradio app.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>To embed with Web Components:\u003C/p>\n\u003Col>\n\u003Cli>Import the gradio JS library into into your site by adding the script below in your site (replace {GRADIO_VERSION} in the URL with the library version of Gradio you are using).\u003C/li>\n\u003C/ol>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>script\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">type\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>module\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">src\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>https://gradio.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/{GRADIO_VERSION}/gradio.js\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>script\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Col start=\"2\">\n\u003Cli>Add\u003C/li>\n\u003C/ol>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">src\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>https://$your_space_host.hf.space\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>element where you want to place the app. Set the \u003Ccode>src=\u003C/code> attribute to your Space's embed URL, which you can find in the \"Embed this Space\" button. For example:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">src\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>https://abidlabs-pytorch-image-classifier.hf.space\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>You can see examples of how web components look \u003Ca href=\"https://www.gradio.app\">on the Gradio landing page\u003C/a>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>You can also customize the appearance and behavior of your web component with attributes that you pass into the \u003Ccode>&lt;gradio-app&gt;\u003C/code> tag:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cul>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>src\u003C/code>: as we've seen, the \u003Ccode>src\u003C/code> attributes links to the URL of the hosted Gradio demo that you would like to embed\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>space\u003C/code>: an optional shorthand if your Gradio demo is hosted on Hugging Face Space. Accepts a \u003Ccode>username/space_name\u003C/code> instead of a full URL. Example: \u003Ccode>gradio/Echocardiogram-Segmentation\u003C/code>. If this attribute attribute is provided, then \u003Ccode>src\u003C/code> does not need to be provided.\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>control_page_title\u003C/code>: a boolean designating whether the html title of the page should be set to the title of the Gradio app (by default \u003Ccode>\"false\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>initial_height\u003C/code>: the initial height of the web component while it is loading the Gradio app, (by default \u003Ccode>\"300px\"\u003C/code>). Note that the final height is set based on the size of the Gradio app.\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>container\u003C/code>: whether to show the border frame and information about where the Space is hosted (by default \u003Ccode>\"true\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>info\u003C/code>: whether to show just the information about where the Space is hosted underneath the embedded app (by default \u003Ccode>\"true\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>autoscroll\u003C/code>: whether to autoscroll to the output when prediction has finished (by default \u003Ccode>\"false\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>eager\u003C/code>: whether to load the Gradio app as soon as the page loads (by default \u003Ccode>\"false\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>theme_mode\u003C/code>: whether to use the \u003Ccode>dark\u003C/code>, \u003Ccode>light\u003C/code>, or default \u003Ccode>system\u003C/code> theme mode (by default \u003Ccode>\"system\"\u003C/code>)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>\u003Ccode>render\u003C/code>: an event that is triggered once the embedded space has finished rendering.\u003C/li>\n\u003C/ul>\n\u003Cp>Here's an example of how to use these attributes to create a Gradio app that does not lazy load and has an initial height of 0px.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">space\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>gradio/Echocardiogram-Segmentation\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">eager\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>true\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\t\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">initial_height\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>0px\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>gradio-app\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>Here's another example of how to use the \u003Ccode>render\u003C/code> event. An event listener is used to capture the \u003Ccode>render\u003C/code> event and will call the \u003Ccode>handleLoadComplete()\u003C/code> function once rendering is complete.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>script\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\tfunction handleLoadComplete() {\n\t\tconsole.log(\"Embedded space has finished rendering\");\n\t}\n\n\tconst gradioApp = document.querySelector(\"gradio-app\");\n\tgradioApp.addEventListener(\"render\", handleLoadComplete);\n\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>script\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cem>Note: While Gradio's CSS will never impact the embedding page, the embedding page can affect the style of the embedded Gradio app. Make sure that any CSS in the parent page isn't so general that it could also apply to the embedded Gradio app and cause the styling to break. Element selectors such as \u003Ccode>header &#123; ... &#125;\u003C/code> and \u003Ccode>footer &#123; ... &#125;\u003C/code> will be the most likely to cause issues.\u003C/em>\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch3  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h3>\n\u003Cp>To embed with IFrames instead (if you cannot add javascript to your website, for example), add this element:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"html\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;\u003C/span>iframe\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token attr-name\">src\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token attr-value\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation attr-equals\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>https://$your_space_host.hf.space\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token tag\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">&lt;/\u003C/span>iframe\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">>\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>Again, you can find the \u003Ccode>src=\u003C/code> attribute to your Space's embed URL, which you can find in the \"Embed this Space\" button.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Note: if you use IFrames, you'll probably want to add a fixed \u003Ccode>height\u003C/code> attribute and set \u003Ccode>style=\"border:0;\"\u003C/code> to remove the border. In addition, if your app requires permissions such as access to the webcam or the microphone, you'll need to provide that as well using the \u003Ccode>allow\u003C/code> attribute.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch2 class=\"group\" id=\"api-page\">API Page\u003Ca href=\"#api-page\" class=\"invisible group-hover-visible\">\u003Cimg\n  src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>You can use almost any Gradio app as an API! In the footer of a Gradio app \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/spaces/gradio/hello_world\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>like this one\u003C/a>, you'll see a \"Use via API\" link.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/blob/main/guides/assets/use_via_api.png?raw=true\"\n  alt=\"Use via API\"\n>\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>This is a page that lists the endpoints that can be used to query the Gradio app, via our supported clients: either \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://gradio.app/guides/getting-started-with-the-python-client/\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>the Python client\u003C/a>, or \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://gradio.app/guides/getting-started-with-the-js-client/\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>the JavaScript client\u003C/a>. For each endpoint, Gradio automatically generates the parameters and their types, as well as example inputs, like this.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/gradio-guides/view-api.png\"\n>\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>The endpoints are automatically created when you launch a Gradio application. If you are using Gradio \u003Ccode>Blocks\u003C/code>, you can also name each event listener, such as\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">btn\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">click\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>add\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">[\u003C/span>num1\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> num2\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">]\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> output\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword-argument attr-name\">api_name\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"addition\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>This will add and document the endpoint \u003Ccode>/addition/\u003C/code> to the automatically generated API page. Read more about the \u003Ca\n  href=\"./view-api-page\"\n>API page here\u003C/a>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch2\n  class=\"group\"\n  id=\"accessing-the-network-request-directly\"\n>Accessing the Network Request Directly\u003Ca\n  href=\"#accessing-the-network-request-directly\"\n  class=\"invisible group-hover-visible\"\n>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>When a user makes a prediction to your app, you may need the underlying network request, in order to get the request headers (e.g. for advanced authentication), log the client's IP address, getting the query parameters, or for other reasons. Gradio supports this in a similar manner to FastAPI: simply add a function parameter whose type hint is \u003Ccode>gr.Request\u003C/code> and Gradio will pass in the network request as that parameter. Here is an example:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> gradio \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">as\u003C/span> gr\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">def\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token function\">echo\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>text\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> request\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">gr\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>Request\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span>\n    \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">if\u003C/span> request\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span>\n        \u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">print\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"Request headers dictionary:\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">request\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>headers\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\n        \u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">print\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"IP address:\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">request\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">client\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>host\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\n        \u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">print\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">launch\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>Note: if your function is called directly instead of through the UI (this happens, for\nexample, when examples are cached, or when the Gradio app is called via API), then \u003Ccode>request\u003C/code> will be \u003Ccode>None\u003C/code>.\nYou should handle this case explicitly to ensure that your app does not throw any errors. That is why\nwe have the explicit check \u003Ccode>if request\u003C/code>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch2\n  class=\"group\"\n  id=\"mounting-within-another-fast-api-app\"\n>Mounting Within Another FastAPI  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>In some cases, you might have an existing FastAPI app, and you'd like to add a path for a Gradio demo.\nYou can easily do this with  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h3>\n\u003Cp>You may wish to put an authentication page in front of your app to limit who can open your app. With the \u003Ccode>auth=\u003C/code> keyword argument in the \u003Ccode>launch()\u003C/code> method, you can provide a tuple with a username and password, or a list of acceptable username/password tuples; Here's an example that provides password-based authentication for a single user named \"admin\":\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">demo\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">launch\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword-argument attr-name\">auth\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"admin\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"pass1234\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>For more complex authentication handling, you can even pass a function that takes a username and password as arguments, and returns \u003Ccode>True\u003C/code> to allow access, \u003Ccode>False\u003C/code> otherwise.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Here's an example of a function that accepts any login where the username and password are the same:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">def\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token function\">same_auth\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>username\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> password\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span>\n    \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">return\u003C/span> username \u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">==\u003C/span> password\n\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">demo\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">launch\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword-argument attr-name\">auth\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">=\u003C/span>same_auth\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>If you have multiple users, you may wish to customize the content that is shown depending on the user that is logged in. You can retrieve the logged in user by \u003Ca\n  href=\"#accessing-the-network-request-directly\"\n>accessing the network request directly\u003C/a> as discussed above, and then reading the \u003Ccode>.username\u003C/code> attribute of the request. Here's an example:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> gradio \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">as\u003C/span> gr\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">def\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token function\">update_message\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>request\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">gr\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>Request\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span>\n    \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">return\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token string-interpolation\">\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">f\"Welcome, \u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token interpolation\">\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">{\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">request\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>username\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">}\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"\u003C/span>\u003C/span>\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">with\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">gr\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">Blocks\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">as\u003C/span> demo\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span>\n    \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword-argument attr-name\">m\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">=\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">gr\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">Markdown\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\n    \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">demo\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">load\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> m\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">demo\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token function-call\">launch\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword-argument attr-name\">auth\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">=\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">[\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"Abubakar\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">,\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token string\">\"Abubakar\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token class=\"token string\">\"Ali\"\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">]\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>Note: For authentication to work properly, third party cookies must be enabled in your browser. This is not the case by default for Safari or for Chrome Incognito Mode.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>If users visit the \u003Ccode>/logout\u003C/code> page of your Gradio app, they will automatically be logged out and session cookies deleted. This allows you to add logout functionality to your Gradio app as well. Let's update the previous example to include a log out button:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token are logged in from multiple browsers or devices, all will be signed out). If you want to log out only from the \u003Cstrong>current session\u003C/strong>, add the query parameter \u003Ccode>all_session=false\u003C/code> (i.e. \u003Ccode>/logout?all_session=false\u003C/code>).\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Note: Gradio's built-in authentication provides a straightforward and basic layer of access control but does not offer robust security features for applications that require stringent access controls (e.g.  multi-factor authentication, rate limiting, or automatic lockout policies).\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch3\n  class=\"group\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h3>\n\u003Cp>Gradio natively supports OAuth login via Hugging Face. In other words, you can easily add a \u003Cem>\"Sign in with Hugging Face\"\u003C/em> button to your demo, which allows you to get a user's HF username as well as other information from their HF profile. Check out \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/spaces/Wauplin/gradio-oauth-demo\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>this Space\u003C/a> for a live demo.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>To enable OAuth, you must set \u003Ccode>hf_oauth: true\u003C/code> as a Space metadata in your README.md file. This will register your Space\nas an OAuth application on Hugging Face. Next, you can use \u003Ccode>gr.LoginButton\u003C/code> to add a login button to\nyour Gradio app. Once a user is logged in with their HF account, you can retrieve their profile by adding a parameter of type\n\u003Ccode>gr.OAuthProfile\u003C/code> to any Gradio function. The user profile will be automatically injected as a parameter value. If you want\nto perform actions on behalf of the user (e.g. list user's private repos, create repo, etc.), you can retrieve the user\ntoken by adding a parameter of type \u003Ccode>gr.OAuthToken\u003C/code>. You must define which scopes you will use in your Space metadata\n(see \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/docs/hub/spaces-oauth#scopes\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>documentation\u003C/a> for more details).\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Here is a short example:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cdiv class=\"codeblock\">\u003Cpre class=\"gradio-code\" data-lang=\"python\">\u003Ccode>\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">from\u003C/span> __future__ \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> annotations\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> gradio \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">as\u003C/span> gr\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">from\u003C/span> huggingface_hub \u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">import\u003C/span> whoami\n\n\u003Cspan class=\"token keyword\">def\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token function\">hello\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">(\u003C/span>profile\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">:\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token namespace\">gr\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">.\u003C/span>OAuthProfile \u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">|\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token builtin-constant constant\">None\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span> \u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">-\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token operator\">>\u003C/span> punctuation\">(\u003C/span>\u003Cspan class=\"token punctuation\">)\u003C/span>\n\u003C/code>\u003C/pre>\u003C/div>\n\u003Cp>When the user clicks on the login button, they get redirected in a new page to authorize your Space.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ccenter>\n\u003Cimg src=\"https://huggingface.co/datasets/huggingface/documentation-images/resolve/main/gradio-guides/oauth_sign_in.png\" style=\"width:300px; max-width:80%\">\n\u003C/center>\n\u003Cp>Users can revoke access to their profile at any time in their \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/settings/connected-applications\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>settings\u003C/a>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>As seen above, OAuth features are available only when your app runs in a Space. However, you often need to test your app\nlocally before deploying it. To test OAuth features locally, your machine must be logged in to Hugging Face. Please run \u003Ccode>huggingface-cli login\u003C/code> or set \u003Ccode>HF_TOKEN\u003C/code> as environment variable with one of your access token. You can generate a new token in your settings page (\u003Ca\n  href=\"https://huggingface.co/settings/tokens\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>https://huggingface.co/settings/tokens\u003C/a>). Then, clicking on the \u003Ccode>gr.LoginButton\u003C/code> will log in to your local Hugging Face profile, allowing you to debug your app with your Hugging Face account before deploying it to a Space.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cstrong>Security Note\u003C/strong>: It is important to note that adding a \u003Ccode>gr.LoginButton\u003C/code> does not restrict users from using your app, in the same way that adding \u003Ca\n  href=\"/guides/sharing-your-app#password-protected-app\"\n>username-password authentication\u003C/a> does. This means that users of your app who have not logged in with Hugging Face can still access and run events in your Gradio app -- the difference is that the \u003Ccode>gr.OAuthProfile\u003C/code> or \u003Ccode>gr.OAuthToken\u003C/code> will be \u003Ccode>None\u003C/code> in the corresponding functions.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch3\n  class=\"group\"\n  id=\"o-auth-with-external-providers\"\n>OAuth (with external providers)\u003Ca\n  href=\"#o-auth-with-external-providers\"\n  class=\"invisible group-hover-visible\"\n>\u003Cimg\n  src=\"data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20fill='%23808080'%20viewBox='0%200%20640%20512'%3e%3c!--!%20Font%20Awesome%20Pro%206.0.0%20by%20@fontawesome%20-%20https://fontawesome.com%20License%20-%20https://fontawesome.com/license%20(Commercial%20License)%20Copyright%202022%20Fonticons,%20Inc.%20--%3e%3cpath%20d='M172.5%20131.1C228.1%2075.51%20320.5%2075.51%20376.1%20131.1C426.1%20181.1%20433.5%20260.8%20392.4%20318.3L391.3%20319.9C381%20334.2%20361%20337.6%20346.7%20327.3C332.3%20317%20328.9%20297%20339.2%20282.7L340.3%20281.1C363.2%20249%20359.6%20205.1%20331.7%20177.2C300.3%20145.8%20249.2%20145.8%20217.7%20177.2L105.5%20289.5C73.99%20320.1%2073.99%20372%20105.5%20403.5C133.3%20431.4%20177.3%20435%20209.3%20412.1L210.9%20410.1C225.3%20400.7%20245.3%20404%20255.5%20418.4C265.8%20432.8%20262.5%20452.8%20248.1%20463.1L246.5%20464.2C188.1%20505.3%20110.2%20498.7%2060.21%20448.8C3.741%20392.3%203.741%20300.7%2060.21%20244.3L172.5%20131.1zM467.5%20380C411%20436.5%20319.5%20436.5%20263%20380C213%20330%20206.5%20251.2%20247.6%20193.7L248.7%20192.1C258.1%20177.8%20278.1%20174.4%20293.3%20184.7C307.7%20194.1%20311.1%20214.1%20300.8%20229.3L299.7%20230.9C276.8%20262.1%20280.4%20306.9%20308.3%20334.8C339.7%20366.2%20390.8%20366.2%20422.3%20334.8L534.5%20222.5C566%20191%20566%20139.1%20534.5%20108.5C506.7%2080.63%20462.7%2076.99%20430.7%2099.9L429.1%20101C414.7%20111.3%20394.7%20107.1%20384.5%2093.58C374.2%2079.2%20377.5%2059.21%20391.9%2048.94L393.5%2047.82C451%206.731%20529.8%2013.25%20579.8%2063.24C636.3%20119.7%20636.3%20211.3%20579.8%20267.7L467.5%20380z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e\"\n  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h3>\n\u003Cp>It is also possible to authenticate with external OAuth providers (e.g. Google OAuth) in your Gradio apps. To do this, first mount your Gradio app within a FastAPI app (\u003Ca\n  href=\"#mounting-within-another-fast-api-app\"\n>as discussed above\u003C/a>). Then, you must write an \u003Cem>authentication function\u003C/em>, which gets the user's username from the OAuth provider and returns it. This function should be passed to the \u003Ccode>auth_dependency\u003C/code> parameter in \u003Ccode>gr.mount_gradio_app\u003C/code>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>Similar to \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://fastapi.tiangolo.com/tutorial/dependencies/\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>FastAPI dependency functions\u003C/a>, the function specified by \u003Ccode>auth_dependency\u003C/code> will run before any Gradio-related route in your FastAPI app. The function should accept a single parameter: the FastAPI \u003Ccode>Request\u003C/code> and return either a string (representing a user's username) or \u003Ccode>None\u003C/code>. If a string is returned, the user will be able to access the Gradio-related routes in your FastAPI app.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>First, let's show a simplistic example to illustrate the  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>Gradio apps can function as MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers, allowing LLMs to use your app's functions as tools. By simply setting \u003Ccode>mcp_server=True\u003C/code> in the \u003Ccode>.launch()\u003C/code> method, Gradio automatically converts your app's functions into MCP tools that can be called by MCP clients like Claude Desktop, Cursor, or Cline. The server exposes tools based on your function names, docstrings, and type hints, and can handle file uploads, authentication headers, and progress updates. You can also create MCP-only functions using \u003Ccode>gr.api\u003C/code> and expose resources and prompts using decorators. For a comprehensive guide on building MCP servers with Gradio, see \u003Ca\n  href=\"https://www.gradio.app/guides/building-mcp-server-with-gradio\"\n  rel=\"nofollow\"\n>Building an MCP Server with  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>When publishing your app publicly, and making it available via API or via MCP server, you might want to set rate limits to prevent users from abusing your app. You can identify users using their IP address (using the \u003Ccode>gr.Request\u003C/code> object \u003Ca href=\"#accessing-the-network-request-directly\">as discussed above\u003C/a>) or, if they are logged in via Hugging Face OAuth, using their username.  class=\"anchor-img\"\n>\u003C/a>\u003C/h2>\n\u003Cp>By default, Gradio collects certain analytics to help us better understand the usage of the \u003Ccode>gradio\u003C/code> library. This includes the following information:\u003C/p>\n\u003Cul>\n\u003Cli>What environment the Gradio app is running on (e.g. Colab Notebook, Hugging Face Spaces)\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>What input/output components are being used in the Gradio app\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>Whether the Gradio app is utilizing certain advanced features, such as \u003Ccode>auth\u003C/code> or \u003Ccode>show_error\u003C/code>\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>The IP address which is used solely to measure the number of unique developers using Gradio\u003C/li>\n\u003Cli>The version of Gradio that is running\u003C/li>\n\u003C/ul>\n\u003Cp>No information is collected from \u003Cem>users\u003C/em> of your Gradio app. If you'd like to disable analytics altogether, you can do so by setting the \u003Ccode>analytics_enabled\u003C/code> parameter to \u003Ccode>False\u003C/code> in \u003Ccode>gr.Blocks\u003C/code>, \u003Ccode>gr.Interface\u003C/code>, or \u003Ccode>gr.ChatInterface\u003C/code>. Or, you can set the GRADIO_ANALYTICS_ENABLED environment variable to \u003Ccode>\"False\"\u003C/code> to apply this to all Gradio apps created across your system.\u003C/p>\n\u003Cp>\u003Cem>Note\u003C/em>: this reflects the analytics policy as of \u003Ccode>gradio&gt;=4.32.0\u003C/code>.\u003C/p>\n\u003Ch2 class=\"group\"
